TQLO, TQLO General
71.1 TQLO General
� General information
The aim of the aggregate TQLO is the determination of the overall torque losses of the engine, which contain
the engine immanent torque losses (i.e. friction and pumping losses), the torque losses of auxiliaries (e.g. air
conditioning compressor, electronic cooling fan, supercharger, etc.) and a compensation of deviations due to
tolerances in series production or aging. The torque losses of the gear box and of the powertrain are not taken
into account.
The aggregate TQLO is available in two variants:
? Variant 01: standard version,
? Variant 02: version for 2-step VVL systems.

71.1.2 Description of containing functions
? Torque losses
The target of the function is the determination of the overall torque losses of the engine. The overall torque
losses TQ_LOSS are calculated as a sum of
? the engine immanent torque losses TQFR, i.e. friction and pumping losses at standard operating tem-
perature,
? TQFR_ADD - the temperature- and
? TQFR_ST - start corrections of the friction losses,
? TQ_DIF_IS_AD - an adaptation of deviations due to tolerances in series production or aging,
? TQ_LOSS_ADD - the torque losses of relevant auxiliary components (e.g. ACC, ECF, etc.),
? TQFR_DELTA_ADD - project-speci?c corrections (e.g. for turbo-, VVT-systems, etc.).
Additionally to TQ_LOSS, this module delivers the ?ltered value of torque losses TQ_LOSS_REQ_CLU used for the
determination of minimum torque at clutch. This is necessary to avoid uncomfortable torque jerks at switching
of additional torque consumers. In order to provide torque-neutral transitions between homogeneous and
strati?ed combustion mode in HPDI-systems, or between different valve lifts in VVL-systems, TQ_LOSS_REQ_
CLU is calculated with MAF-independent friction losses TQFR_MEC.
? Coordination of additional torque losses
In this module the additional torque losses of external consumers (e.g., TQ_LOSS_ACC - torque losses of
air conditioning compressor, TQ_LOSS_ECF - of electric cooling fan, etc.) are summed up. TQ_LOSS_ADD
expresses the overall additional torque losses and is the interface to moduleTorque Losses.
? Correction of friction and pumping losses
This module allows project-speci?c correctons and extensions of the model for the engine torque losses (e.g.
taking into account Turbo-, VVT-systems, etc.). The output TQFR_DELTA_ADD is the interface to moduleTorque
Losses.
? (TQM) Idle speed adaptation - Adaptation algorithm
The task of the functionality Idle speed adaptation is to compensate possible deviations in torque losses that
can vary due to aging or tolerances in series production. The adaptation of torque losses of engine, hydraulic
converter and air conditioning compressor (as the most signi?cant torque consumers) is calculated during
idle speed, using the integral part TQ_DIF_I_IS of the idle speed controller. The basic IS adaptation torque TQ_
DIF_IS_AD is always considered in the module ?Torque Losses?, where it is added to engine torque losses.

The adaptation of torque losses of engine, hydraulic
converter and air conditioning compressor (as the most signi?cant torque consumers) is calculated during
idle speed, using the integral part TQ_DIF_I_IS of the idle speed controller. The basic IS adaptation torque TQ_
DIF_IS_AD is always considered in the module ?Torque Losses?, where it is added to engine torque losses. The
output TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC is considered in the calculation of the air conditioning compressor losses (?Torque
Loss and Lead for ACC?), whenever the ACC is switched on. TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV is used in the converter
torque calculation module (?Converter Torque?).
? (TQM) Idle speed adaptation - Adaptation conditions
This second module of the adaptation algorithm checks whether the adaptation conditions are ful?lled. The
following conditions are to be checked: 1) engine running in idle state (LV_REQ_ISC=1), 2) idle speed has settled

for a given time delay, 3) vehicle stopped (LV_VS_RUN = 0), 4) coolant temperature is in operating range, 5)
application incidence conditions are ful?lled (LV_IS_AD_INH = 0).
If one of these conditions is not ful?lled, the logical variable LV_AD_CDN_IS is not set and so the adaptation
algorithm will not be executed. This should avoid bad adaptation.
? (TQM) Idle speed adaptation - Appication incidences
The module Application Incidence coordinates a range of error bits. If one of these error bits is set, the
adaptation algorithm will not be executed to avoid bad adaptation.

� General Information
The adaptation process is released when all of the following conditions are ful?lled (LV_AD_CDN_IS = 1):
- engine running in idle state (LV_REQ_ISC = 1)
- vehicle stopped (LV_VS_RUN = 0)
- coolant temperature in operating range
- LV_IS_AD_INH_OBD = 0 (see module "Application Incidence").
- LV_IS_AD_INH = 0 (see module "Application Incidence").
- idle speed has settled for a given time delay (T_DLY_AD_IS is the timer value):

71.4.2.4 Inhibition of STST due to torque loss adaption
As long as none adaption has never been performed, the STST strategy is inhibited and the engine is forced to
stay in idle speed state. The torque loss adaption can now be performed.
Otherwise the engine may never stay in idle state -STST stops the engine-, and an idle speed adaption would
be never performed
A ?rst adaption in the vehicle story is mandatory, and as long as this is not ?nished, the inhibition for STST is
kept
An adaption is considered as ?nished when the idle speed controllers I-share is close to 0 Nm.
In order to keep torque accuracy, the STST strategy is inhibited again after a certain number of start STST
cycles without any ?nished adaption.
Once the adaption has ?nished, the overall cycle start number where it happened is saved in the NVMY and
the inhibition for STST is removed
If the engine stays on idle for other reasons -such as low battery voltage, open driver door, etc..- an adaption can
be carried out and ?nished without activating the inhibition. In this case the counter would be updated too, so
the start cycles until next inhibition is reset

71.4.2.5 Adaption of the frequency for STST inhibition
Due to STST feature, it may be possible that engine never stays at idle under the conditions that allow a torque
losses adaption.
For this reason, the STST is inhibited after a certain number of engine start events without a successfully torque
adaption.
The number of engine starts until inhibition request -or frequency for inhibition of STST-is learned too.
Different cases are possible:
- STST is inhibited. When the adaption starts, the current torque deviation is checked. If this is lower than
a threshold, it?s considered that it was not required to perform the adaption, so inhibition frequency can be
reduced. As the torque deviation is lower than the threshold, the adaption is considered as ?nished
- STST is inhibited. When the adaption starts, the current torque deviation is checked. If this is higher than
a threshold, it?s considered that it?s necessary to adapt oftener. Therefore the inhibition frequency must be
increased.
In this second case, it? assured that after reducing the counter, the inhibition is kept as long as the torque
adaption did not yet ?nished by means of the control ?ag LV_CTR_AD_END_ST_STST_IS_AD. This ?ag is saved
in the NVMY, so the functionality can remember ever after ECU reset that the frequency was already adapted
and the torque adaption must still be ?nished.
If for any reason the torque error cannot be reduced below the expected limit -adaption cannot be ?nished-
,although the inhibition is active and engine stays in idle speed, the cycle counter is updated and the inhibition
is removed. Otherwise STST maybe disabled for the rest of vehicle life

TQLO, TQM - Idle speed adaptation algorithm
The torque losses of engine and components can vary due to aging or tolerances in series production. Be-
cause these effects cannot be taken into account by calibration, it is the task of the functionality ?Idle speed
adaptation? to compensate possible deviations in torque losses. Based on the integral part TQ_DIF_I_IS of the
idle speed controller, the functionality calculates deviations in torque losses of engine, converter and air con-
ditioning compressor (as the most signi?cant torque consumers).
The module outputs are considered in relevant functions. The basic IS adaptation torque TQ_DIF_IS_AD is
always considered in the module "Torque Losses" where it is added to engine torque losses. The output TQ_
DIF_IS_AD_ACC is considered in the calculation of the air conditioning compressor losses ( Torque Loss and
Lead for ACC ), whenever the ACC is switched on and authorized. TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV is considered then in
the converter torque calculation module ( Converter Torque ).
The outputs of different adaptation paths are always covered with values of the last adaptation, even if the
adaptation conditions are not ful?lled or the engine is not in idle. But these values will only be adapted
(changed) if the certain adaptation path is activated.

71.5.1.2 Adaptation algorithm
As soon as the adaptation conditions are ful?lled (LV_AD_CDN_IS = 1), one of four adaptation parameters is
calculated dependent on the actual situation:
The intermediate value of basic adaptation of the idle speed controller (TQ_DIF_IS_AD_INTER) is calculated if the
gear is disengaged (LV_DRI = 0) and the air conditioning compressor is switched off (LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH
= 0).
The intermediate value TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV_INTER for the hydraulic converter torque adaptation is calculated
if LV_DRI = 1 and LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH = 0.
The adaptation of the air conditioning compressor is performed if LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH = 1. This is the
case when ACC is switched on and the last adaptation value is valid (positive adaptation values shall be

TQLO, TQM - Idle speed adaptation algorithm

AD_ACC_CONV_INTER is calculated for LV_DRI = 1.
A fraction of the integral part of the idle speed controller (C_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD_xx * TQ_DIF_I_IS) is added at
each cycle to the concerned adaptation parameter, whose value is limited through a min/max limiter. The
integration is done with high resolution values (long signed word, xxx_INTER). These long signed word values
are stored (in block ?NMVY data?) and used as start values after re-entering into the same adaptation path.
The speed of the adaptation process is de?ned through the calibration parameter C_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD_xx
and the function s update rate (100ms), and should be very slow compared to variations of the integral part of
the idle speed controller (C_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD_xx <<1). In this case, the compensation of the added torque
request is done automatically by the idle speed controller.
71.5.1.2.1 Adaptation algorithm
As soon as the adaptation conditions are ful?lled (LV_AD_CDN_IS = 1), one of four adaptation parameters is
calculated dependent on the actual situation:
The intermediate value of basic adaptation of the idle speed controller (TQ_DIF_IS_AD_INTER) is calculated if the
gear is disengaged (LV_DRI = 0) and the air conditioning compressor is switched off (LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH
= 0).
The intermediate value TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV_INTER for the hydraulic converter torque adaptation is calculated
if LV_DRI = 1 and LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH = 0.
The adaptation of the air conditioning compressor is performed if LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH = 1. This is the
case when ACC is switched on and the last adaptation value is valid (positive adaptation values shall be
avoided). TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC_1_INTER is calculated if the gear is disengaged (LV_DRI = 0), while TQ_DIF_IS_
AD_ACC_CONV_INTER is calculated for LV_DRI = 1.
A fraction of the integral part of the idle speed controller (C_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD_xx * TQ_DIF_I_IS) is added at
each cycle to the concerned adaptation parameter, whose value is limited through a min/max limiter. The
integration is done with high resolution values (long signed word, xxx_INTER). These long signed word values
are stored (in block ?NMVY data?) and used as start values after re-entering into the same adaptation path.
The speed of the adaptation process is de?ned through the calibration parameter C_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD_xx
and the function s update rate (100ms), and should be very slow compared to variations of the integral part of
the idle speed controller (C_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD_xx <<1). In this case, the compensation of the added torque
request is done automatically by the idle speed controller.

71.5.2.2 Preparation of torque adaptation outputs
In this block, the outputs of the idle speed adaptation functionality are calculated. This block is activated at
every engine state and not only at idle speed.
The intermediate value TQ_DIF_IS_AD_INTER is converted from high resolution (signed long word) to normal
resolution (signed word). Only the high word is taken from the signed long word value. The converted value
is multiplied with engine-speed and coolant-temperature dependent fade-out factor IP_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD to
produce an output TQ_DIF_IS_AD.
The intermediate value TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV_INTER is converted from high resolution to normal resolution.
The value is multiplied with engine-speed and coolant-temperature dependent correction factor IP_FAC_TQ_
DIF_IS_AD_CONV. This gives an output TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV.
Since the ACC torque losses module uses one input TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC, a selection of ACC adaptation torque
between TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC_1_INTER and TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC_CONV_INTER is made in dependence on the ac-
tual situation. The intermediate values TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC_1_INTER and TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC_CONV_INTER are
converted from high resolution (signed long word) to normal resolution (signed word) and sent to a switch. To
prevent abrupt changes, the output value of this swith is smoothed by a low pass ?lter. The smoothed value
is multiplied with engine-speed and coolant-temperature dependent correction factor IP_FAC_TQ_DIF_IS_AD_
ACC.
The changes of all adaptation values at a recurrence step are summed up in the output TQ_DELTA_DIF_IS_AD
which is used for correction of I-part term TQ_DIF_I_IS of idle-speed controller.

� General Information
Target of the module Torque Losses is the determination of the engine immanent losses (frictional and pump-
ing losses).
This version of the module is speci?c for two-step variable-valve lift (VVL) system.

TQLO, Torque losses
The output parameters of the module are the overall torque losses TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL, which are cylinder
bank- and valve-lift speci?c, the engine overall torque losses TQ_LOSS_ENG and start correction of engine
friction losses TQFR_ST.
The calculation of TQ_LOSS_ENG requires the import of quantities from related modules. These are :
TQ_DIF_IS_AD: The idle speed adaptation torque corrects deviations of engine immanent torque losses due to
tolerances in series production. It is provided by the function Idle speed adaptation .
TQFR_DELTA_ADD: Corrective parameter for the friction and pumping losses. It is calculated in the module
Correction of friction and pumping losses . So the model for the friction and pumping losses can be corrected
or extended for project-speci?c purposes (e.g. Turbo, VVT,..)
Some features are not required for every project, so the can disabled by means of a con?guration switch.
Following table shows the impact of the con?guration switch for this speci?cation #NC_CONF_TQLO_D004
Con?guration switch bit Enabled feature
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 0 0: Friction and pumping losses do not take into account port ?aps
1: Friction and pumping losses take into account port ?aps in?uence
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 1 1: Enable additional correction of friction and pumping losses during catalyst
heating phase.
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 2 Not used
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 3 Not used
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 4 Not used
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 5 Not used
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 6 Not used
#NC_CONF_TQLO_D004 7 Not used

71.6.1.2 Data initialization at ES2ERU
71.6.1.2.1 Data initialization of TQFR_ST
At transition from engine stop LV_ES = 1 to engine run LV_ERU = 1 the friction torque during engine start LV_ST
= 1 is determined depending on TOIL and T_ES_H; the cycle counter CYC_CAST is clamped at 0 cycles. This is
due to the fact, that during engine start the cycle counter CYC_CAST is incremented each combustion cycle
and reset to 0 at the transition to after start (LV_ST_END=1) which would cause a non linearity in TQFR_ST.

TQLO, Torque losses
71.6.2 Correction for friction after start
71.6.2.1 Correction for friction after start TQFR_ST
The increased friction torque loss right after start TQFR_ST is calculated as a function of engine oil temperature
TOIL and of the cycle counter after start CYC_CAST (LV_ST_END=1). Additionaly the time when engine state
is ?engine stopped? (T_ES_H) with ignition key on is considered to take into consideration the oil distribution in
the engine. TQFR_ST_1 is initialised during transition from "engine stop" to "engine run" (see subsystem "OPM__
10MS/INI/INI_ES2ERU"). As soon as the start process has been ?nished (LV_ST_END = 1), TQFR_ST_1 is calculated
from the map IP_TQFR_ST_CYC.
After the counter CYC_CAST as reached FFFFH (65535dez) or LV_ST_END is reset the interpolation of the map
IP_TQFR_ST_CYC is stopped and the last calculated value of TQFR_ST is frozen. Therefore it has to be insured
that the value in the map IP_TQFR_ST_CYC is calibrated to 0Nm at least at the last CYC_CAST breakpoint.
TQFR_ST is required for the determination of the overall torque losses.

71.6.3 Overall Engine Torque losses TQ_LOSS_ENG
In this block the un?ltered overall engine torque losses are calculated. TQ_LOSS_ENG contains the engine
immanent losses, the project-speci?c extensions, the correction for temperature and after-start phase, the
adaptation torque from the idle speed adaptation.
First, the bank- and valve lift-speci?c losses TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL are calculated by use of the bank- and
valve lift-speci?c mass air ?ow MAF_STK_CBK_AV. Then, the actual value of TQ_LOSS_ENG is found as a bank-
average of TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL with actual valve lift for each bank.

71.6.3.1.4 Calculation of bank- and valve lift-speci?c torque losses
Bank- and valve lift-speci?c friction and pumping losses TQFR_CBK_SEL and overall engine torque losses TQ_
LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL are calculated in this block by use of bank- and valve lift-speci?c mass air ?ow MAF_STK_
CBK.
Please note that the friction and pumping losses TQFR_CBK_SEL depend not only on the engine speed N
and mass air ?ow MAF_STK_CBK, but also on the port ?ap position as well as the camshaft positions CAM_IN
and CAM_EX. A special interpolation procedure is used to calculate TQFR_CBK_SEL for such a 5-dimensional
dependence.
71.6.3.1.4.1 Interpolation procedure for calculation of TQFR_CBK_SEL with and without port ?aps
This algorithm is dedicated only for con?gurations with NC_CBK_IN_NR = NC_NR_CBK_IVVT.
TQFR_CBK_SEL[NC_CBK_IN_NR][NC_NR_CASE_VVL] is obtained by means of an interpolation routine from the
maps array:
- For systems with port ?ap(s): IP_TQFR_VVL_CAM_PORT_L[NC_NR_CASE_VVL] [NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_IN] [NC_NR_
IDX_IVVT_EX] and IP_TQFR_VVL_CAM_PORT_H[NC_NR_CASE_VVL] [NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_IN] [NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_EX].
- For systems without port ?ap(s): IP_TQFR_VVL_CAM [NC_NR_CASE_VVL] [NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_IN] [NC_NR_IDX_
IVVT_EX]

� Function Description
General Information
To compensate for lower torque losses at higher altitudes an additive correction for the friction and pumping
losses can be calibrated depending on the current AMP.
Also, if the switchable oil-pump is available, torque friction is compensatable depending on oil temperature and
engine speed. The output TQFR_DELTA_ADD is the interface to module "Torque Losses".

TQLO, Idle speed adaptation (gen)
71.8 Idle speed adaptation (gen)
� Calibration interfering function:
The calibration of the Idle speed adaptation is affected by changes in the calibration of the Torque Model and
the Idle Speed Controller.
� Calibration ?owchart:
1. Switch off the idle speed controller (i.e. tune all maps to 
zero and use the default data for the adaptation algorithm, 
which is off in this case) and check if the engine runs self- 
stabled without idle speed controller and without additional 
load on engine. This means check that the engine runs 
correctly and that the application prerequisites are fulfilled. 
Tuning the idle speed controller doesn't make any sense if any 
of these conditions is not fulfilled. If speed is oscillating very 
strongly or the engine stalls, you must check all the other 
modules first. Fix the throttle, check the ignition angle working 
correctly and opposite 
2. Start the tuning of the ISC with the functionality "Idle Speed 
Torque reserve due to low Engine Speed" 
3. Tuning of the I-part of the controller 
4. Tuning of the PD-part of the controller 
5. Calibration the Idle Speed adaptation 
algorithm 
6. Overall Test 
7. Calibration of ISC with Drivetrain engaged

1. Measurement procedure 
The measurements of the motoring torque have 
to be done for each valve lift position. 
The measurement should be performed on a 
warm engine (TCO ca. 90�C). It is recommended 
to run a joint measurement program for the 
calibration of the torque loss model and the 
indicated torque model. 
 
2. Breakpoint selection for measurement : 
The measurements for different valve lifts have 
to be done in the whole operating range for the 
respective VVL position each.   
N : N_IS - 200 rpm, N_IS, N_IS + 200 rpm,    
1000 rpm ... N_MAX (delta N = 500rpm) 
MAF : MAFidle, 100mg/stk  ... MAF_MAX (delta 
MAF = 50mg/stk) 
EGR : 0 % 
 
3. Data evaluation 
The tool ?Interactive Control Development and 
Parameterization? (ICDP Version V4.0 with 
SPT_ui) will be used for the numerical 
optimization of the measurement data and the 
parameterization of the model. 
After the selection of the database for the basic 
optimization, the user will be guided through the 
optimization process by the user interface of the 
ICDP-tool. Here some recommendations for the 
optimization/parameterization: 
The overall goal for the optimization / 
parameterization process is an absolute model 
accuracy of � 1Nm. So the first focus should be 
to reach this accuracy without paying too much 
attention to smoothness and monotony of the 
maps. After the requirements on accuracy have 
been met, the weights for smoothness and 
monotony can be gradually increased. 
In most cases, overly steep slopes, holes, peaks 
etc.  do not represent actual physical 
relationships, and thus, are not acceptable in the 
maps. They are often the result of interpolations 
/ extrapolations, and are not supported by actual 
measurement data. If an irregularity like that is 
detected, the tool enables the user to manually 
change these points. After a manual adjustment, 
the model accuracy has to be tested again.

C_MAF_CYL_STK_REF  In HPDI-systems that operate in both 
homogeneous and stratified combustion mode,

derived from TQFR_MEC and does not depend 
on MAF. Therefore, a constant TQ_REQ_CLU 
during transitions between homogeneous and 
stratified combustion mode can be assured.  
Hint : If C_MAF_CYL_STK_REF is set to the 
value of the maximum MAF_CYL_STK-break-
point, TQFR_MEC represents the engine losses 
at wide open throttle. At this reference point the 
pumping losses are minimized and TQFR_MEC 
is assumed to be equivalent to the mechanical 
friction losses. 
The MAF-dependency of TQFR does not cause 
any problems in systems with port injection. So 
with regard to comfortable transitions from PL to 
PU, it is recommended to set the variable 
C_MAF_CYL_STK_REF to zero.

## Function

The Simulink diagram represents a module that calculates the overall torque losses of an engine. This module incorporates various factors, including inherent engine losses, corrections for temperature and starting, adaptation for manufacturing tolerances and aging, losses from auxiliary components, and project-specific corrections. It also includes idle speed adaptation algorithms to compensate for torque loss variations during idle.

## Inputs

*   **TQ_LOSS_xxx:** Additional torque losses.
*   **N:** Engine speed.
*   **MAF_STK_CBK:** Mass airflow data.
*   **NR_ACK_CBK_VVL:** Engine acknowledge signal.
*   **CYC_CAST:** Engine status.
*   **TCO:** Temperature-dependent torque loss.
*   **N_DIF:** Difference in engine speed.
*   **LV_REQ_ISC:** Idle Speed Control Request
*   **LV_VS_RUN:** Engine running condition.
*   **LV_IS_AD_INH:** Inhibit idle speed adaptation.
*   **LV_IS_AD_INH_OBD:** Inhibit idle speed adaptation due to OBD.
*   **LV_ACCOUT_RLY:** Air Conditioning compressor relay state.
*   **LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH:** Idle speed adaptation authorize.
*   **LV_AD_CDN_IS:** Adaptation Conditions.
*   **LV_ST_END:** Engine end event.
*   **LV_DRI:** Idle Speed Controller Drive.
*   **TQ_DIF_I_IS:** Integrated Idle speed torque difference.
*   Other "proj.spec. inputs" related to friction and pumping loss corrections.

## Outputs

*   **TQ_LOSS:** Overall torque losses.
*   **TQ_LOSS_REQ_CLU:** Filtered torque losses for clutch control.
*   **TQFR_ST:** Start corrections of the friction losses.
*   **TQ_LOSS_CBK_SEL:** Torque loss callback selection.
*   **TQ_DIF_IS_AD:** Basic IS adaptation torque.
*   **TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV:** Adaptation converter torque.
*   **TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC:** Adaptation acceleration torque.
*   **TQ_DELTA_DIF_IS_AD:** Delta IS adaption torque.
*   **TQ_LOSS_ADD:** Additional torque losses (external consumers).
*   **TQFR_DELTA_ADD:** Project-specific corrections to friction and pumping losses.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Input Collection:** The module receives various inputs, categorized as additional torque losses (TQ_LOSS_xxx), project-specific inputs, error symptoms, adaptation conditions, adaptation algorithm parameters, and engine operating parameters.
2.  **Coordination of Additional Torque Losses:** The additional torque losses from external consumers are summed up to produce TQ_LOSS_ADD.
3.  **Correction of Friction and Pumping Losses:** Project-specific corrections and extensions are applied to the friction and pumping losses, resulting in TQFR_DELTA_ADD.
4.  **Adaptation Conditions Check:** The module checks if the adaptation conditions are fulfilled based on LV_REQ_ISC, engine speed etc.
5.  **Idle Speed Adaptation Algorithm:** Based on the adaptation algorithm block, the correction values for the basic IS adaptation torque (TQ_DIF_IS_AD), converter torque (TQ_DIF_IS_AD_CONV), and ACC-related torque (TQ_DIF_IS_AD_ACC) are calculated.
6.  **Torque Loss Calculation:** The module integrates all the inputs to determine the overall torque losses (TQ_LOSS) of the engine. The exact calculation involves summing TQFR (friction and pumping losses), TQFR_ADD (temperature correction), TQFR_ST (start correction), TQ_DIF_IS_AD (adaptation torque), TQ_LOSS_ADD (auxiliary component losses), and TQFR_DELTA_ADD (project-specific corrections).
7.  **Filtered Torque Loss Calculation:** Calculate a filtered torque loss, TQ_LOSS_REQ_CLU.
8.  **Output Generation:** The module outputs the calculated overall torque losses (TQ_LOSS), along with intermediate values like the filtered torque loss, start correction, adaptation torque values, and other relevant signals.

## Function

This Simulink diagram describes a logic block for inhibiting idle speed adaptation in an engine control system (TQLO/TQM - Idle speed adaptation). The block determines whether or not idle speed adaptation should be allowed based on a set of input conditions and an initialization state.

## Inputs

The diagram has the following inputs:

*   **Initial conditions (fc_INI):** Indicates initialization state.
*   **Several boolean signals** These come from various sensors, diagnostic checks, and system states.

The block determines whether or not idle speed adaptation should be allowed based on a set of input conditions and an initialization state.

## Inputs

The diagram has the following inputs:

*   **Initial conditions (fc_INI):** Indicates initialization state.
*   **Several boolean signals** These come from various sensors, diagnostic checks, and system states. Some examples include:
    *   \<LV\_ET\_ACT\>
    *   \<LV\_OFF\_MTC\_MON\>
    *   \<LV\_IS\_AD\_INH\_TCU2\>
    *   \<TQ\_LOSS\_PSTE\>
    *   \<LV\_ACCOUT\_RLY\>
    *   \<TQ\_LOSS\_ACC\>
    *   \<TQ\_DIF\_I\_IS\>
    *   \<TOIL\>
    *   \<LV\_ACT\_EOL\>
    *   \<LV\_EOL\_OBD\>
    *   \<LV\_ACR\_TST\_ACT\>
    *   \<ACTION\_FARM\_GetPermission\>
    *   \<NC\_CBK\_EX\_NR\>
    *   \<NC\_NR\_CBK\_IVVT\>

## Outputs

The diagram has the following boolean outputs:

*   \<LV\_ACCOUT\_IS\_AD\_AUTH\>: Indicates if adaptation is authorized (allowed).
*   \<LV\_IS\_AD\_INH\>: Indicates if adaptation is inhibited.
*   \<LV\_IS\_AD\_INH\_OBD\>: Indicates if adaptation is inhibited due to OBD constraints.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initialization:** The block is initialized (RST) at startup.
2.  **Periodic Execution:** The block executes periodically every 100ms.
3.  **Input Signal Processing (OPM X.2):** All boolean input signals are fed into an operation block (`OPM X.2`). This block likely combines these input signals using logical AND or OR operations to determine if any of the inhibition conditions are true.
4.  **Initialization (INI X.1):** The initialization signal (`fc_INI`) is fed into another block (`INI X.1`).
5.  **Overall Inhibition Logic:** The outputs of input signals (`OPM X.2`) and Initialization signal (`INI X.1`) are fed into a block (`V.6.4`), which performs the final logic to determine the inhibition status. This block likely prioritizes certain inhibition conditions over others and uses the initialization state to ensure proper behavior during startup. The logic within this block determines the output signals, indicating whether adaptation is authorized or inhibited for various reasons (overall, due to OBD, etc.).
6.  **Output Signals:** The final output signals are generated: `LV_ACCOUT_IS_AD_AUTH`, `LV_IS_AD_INH`, and `LV_IS_AD_INH_OBD`. These signals are then used by other parts of the idle speed control system to enable or disable adaptation as needed.

## Function

The Simulink diagram calculates an inhibition value based on two inputs related to torque loss due to PSTE (potentially Stationary Test Equipment). The primary purpose is to determine if an idle speed adaptation should be inhibited based on PSTE-related torque losses.

## Inputs

*   `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`: Torque loss due to PSTE.
*   `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD`: Threshold value for PSTE torque loss that inhibits the idle speed adaptation.

## Outputs

*   `LV_IS_AD_INH_PSTE`: A boolean value that indicates whether the idle speed adaptation should be inhibited. A value of 1 indicates that the idle speed adaptation is inhibited.

## Logic Flow

1.  The signal `TQ_LOSS_PSTE` represents the torque loss attributed to the potentially stationary test equipment (PSTE).
2.  The signal `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD` represents the calibrated threshold value for the PSTE torque loss. This threshold is used to determine if the idle speed adaptation should be inhibited.
3.  The 'Greater Than' comparator (V.6.2) compares the values of `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD` and `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`.  The comparator checks if `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD > TQ_LOSS_PSTE`
4.  If `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD` is greater than `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`, the comparator outputs 1.

The 'Greater Than' comparator (V.6.2) compares the values of `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD` and `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`.  The comparator checks if `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD > TQ_LOSS_PSTE`
4.  If `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD` is greater than `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`, the comparator outputs 1. If `C_TQ_LOSS_PSTE_THD_IS_AD` is less than or equal to `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`, the output is 0.
5.  The output of the comparator is then assigned to the `LV_IS_AD_INH_PSTE` signal, which represents the inhibition status of the idle speed adaptation.  A '1' indicates the idle speed adaptation is inhibited.

In summary, the idle speed adaptation is inhibited if the calibrated threshold is greater than the measured torque loss. This logic likely prevents unnecessary idle speed adaptation when the torque loss due to PSTE is below a certain acceptable level.

## Function

The Simulink diagram calculates conditions for idle speed adaptation. It is split into two main calculations: dynamic delay adaptation (figure 71.4.4) and temperature condition (figure 71.4.5). Ultimately, these computations determine whether adaptation is authorized based on dynamic delay and temperature ranges.

## Inputs

**Figure 71.4.4 (Dynamic Delay):**

*   `LV_DLY_AD_IS_PREV`: Previous value of the dynamic delay adaptation status (Logical).
*   `T_DLY_AD_IS_PREV`: Previous value of the dynamic delay adaptation status (Logical).
*   `C_DLY_AD_IS`: Condition for dynamic delay adaptation (Analog).
*   `N_DIF`: Difference in engine speed (Analog).

**Figure 71.4.5 (Temperature Condition):**

*   `TCO`: Temperature of coolant (Analog).
*   `TOIL`: Temperature of engine oil (Analog).
*   `C_TCO_AD_MAX_IS`: Maximum coolant temperature threshold (Analog).
*   `C_TCO_AD_MIN_IS`: Minimum coolant temperature threshold (Analog).
*   `C_TOIL_H_IS_AD`: Maximum engine oil temperature threshold (Analog).
*   `C_TOIL_L_IS_AD`: Minimum engine oil temperature threshold (Analog).

## Outputs

**Figure 71.4.4 (Dynamic Delay):**

*   `LV_DLY_AD_IS`: Dynamic delay adaptation status (Logical).
*   `T_DLY_AD_IS`: Dynamic delay adaptation status (Logical).

**Figure 71.4.5 (Temperature Condition):**

*   `LV_TCO_AD_CDN_IS`: Coolant temperature adaptation condition status (Logical).
*   `LV_TEMP_ENG_AD_CDN_IS`: Engine temperature adaptation condition status (Logical).

## Logic Flow

**Figure 71.4.4 (Dynamic Delay):**

1.  **Delay and Filtering:**
    *   The inputs `LV_DLY_AD_IS_PREV` and `T_DLY_AD_IS_PREV` represent the previous values of the dynamic delay adaptation status.
    *   `C_DLY_AD_IS` is added to 0.1.
    *   The result is compared using "less than" to `C_DLY_AD_IS` to add a hysteresis/delay.
2.  **Switching Logic:**
    *   If `N_DIF` is equal to 0, the output of the comparator is 1. Otherwise, the output is taken from the comparison with 0.
3.  **Delta Comparison:**
    *   `C_N_DELTA` represents a reference value to compare `N_DIF` with.  If `N_DIF` is less than `C_N_DELTA`, the output is 1.
4.  **Final Switching and Outputs:**
    *   Two switches, controlled by `N_DIF` comparison, select between 0 and outputs of previous comparators, generating the final dynamic adaptation status outputs `LV_DLY_AD_IS` and `T_DLY_AD_IS`.

**Figure 71.4.5 (Temperature Condition):**

1.  **Coolant Temperature Checks:**
    *   The engine coolant temperature `TCO` is compared against a maximum threshold `C_TCO_AD_MAX_IS` using a "less than or equal to" comparator.
    *   `TCO` is also compared against a minimum threshold `C_TCO_AD_MIN_IS` using a "greater than or equal to" comparator.
2.

**Figure 71.4.5 (Temperature Condition):**

1.  **Coolant Temperature Checks:**
    *   The engine coolant temperature `TCO` is compared against a maximum threshold `C_TCO_AD_MAX_IS` using a "less than or equal to" comparator.
    *   `TCO` is also compared against a minimum threshold `C_TCO_AD_MIN_IS` using a "greater than or equal to" comparator.
2.  **Oil Temperature Checks:**
    *   The engine oil temperature `TOIL` is compared against a maximum threshold `C_TOIL_H_IS_AD` using a "less than or equal to" comparator.
    *   `TOIL` is also compared against a minimum threshold `C_TOIL_L_IS_AD` using a "greater than or equal to" comparator.
3.  **AND Logic:**
    *   The outputs of the coolant temperature comparators are fed into an AND block. This block outputs 1 only if `TCO` is within the defined range (`C_TCO_AD_MIN_IS` <= `TCO` <= `C_TCO_AD_MAX_IS`).
    *   The outputs of the oil temperature comparators are fed into an AND block. This block outputs 1 only if `TOIL` is within the defined range (`C_TOIL_L_IS_AD` <= `TOIL` <= `C_TOIL_H_IS_AD`).
4.  **Final Outputs:**
    *   The output of the coolant temperature AND block is `LV_TCO_AD_CDN_IS`.
    *   The output of the oil temperature AND block is `LV_TEMP_ENG_AD_CDN_IS`.

## Function

The Simulink diagram represents the logic for determining if the Start-Stop (STST) strategy should be inhibited due to conditions related to idle speed adaptation.  Specifically, it evaluates both dynamic and static adaptation conditions and outputs a signal indicating whether the adaptation conditions are met.

## Inputs

*   `<LV_REQ_ISC>`: Logical signal indicating if idle speed control is requested.
*   `<LV_DLY_AD_IS>`: Logical signal indicating a delay in adaptation completion.
*   `<LV_VS_RUNS>`: Logical signal related to vehicle speed.
*   `<LV_TEMP_ENG_AD_CDN_IS>`: Logical signal representing engine temperature adaptation conditions.
*   `<LV_IS_AD_INH_OBD>`: Logical signal representing inhibition of adaptation related to On-Board Diagnostics (OBD).
*   `<LV_IS_AD_INH>`: Logical signal representing a general adaptation inhibit signal.

## Outputs

*   `<LV_AD_CDN_IS>`: Logical signal indicating if adaptation conditions are met.  This likely signals whether the STST system should be inhibited or allowed to operate.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Dynamic Adaptation Conditions:**
    *   `<LV_REQ_ISC>` and `<LV_DLY_AD_IS>` are logically ANDed.
    *   `<LV_VS_RUNS>` is logically NOTed.
    *   The output of the AND gate and the NOT gate are then logically ANDed.

2.  **Static Adaptation Conditions:**
    *   `<LV_TEMP_ENG_AD_CDN_IS>` is an input.
    *   `<LV_IS_AD_INH_OBD>` is logically NOTed.
    *   `<LV_IS_AD_INH>` is logically NOTed.
    *   The outputs of the two NOT gates are logically ANDed.
    *   The output of the above AND gate and `<LV_TEMP_ENG_AD_CDN_IS>` are ANDed.

3.  **Final Output:**
    *   The outputs from the Dynamic Adaptation Conditions and Static Adaptation Conditions sections are logically ANDed to produce the final output signal, `<LV_AD_CDN_IS>`.

In essence, `<LV_AD_CDN_IS>` is TRUE only if all the dynamic and static adaptation conditions are simultaneously met.  The NOT gates likely represent inhibitory signals; for instance, if `LV_VS_RUNS` is TRUE (indicating the vehicle is moving), the STST adaptation may be inhibited. Similarly, if adaptation is already inhibited by `<LV_IS_AD_INH_OBD>` or `<LV_IS_AD_INH>`, the adaptation conditions will not be met and STST is likely blocked.

## Function

The Simulink diagram implements the logic for adapting the frequency of Stop-Start System (STST) inhibition. The objective is to learn the appropriate number of engine starts before inhibiting STST to prevent it from hindering torque adaptation.  It does this by monitoring the torque deviation and adjusting a counter that determines how often the STST is inhibited.

## Inputs

*   **Enable:** Overall system enable signal.
*   **LV_FIRST_STST_IS_AD_old:**  A boolean flag indicating if this is the first STST adaptation attempt (previous value).
*   **LV_TEMP_ENG_AD_CDN_IS:** A boolean signal indicating engine temperature adaptation conditions are met.
*   **TQ_DIF_I_IS:**  Current torque deviation value.
*   **C_TQ_DIF_I_IS_AD_REQ:** Torque deviation adaptation request threshold.
*   **LV_END_STST_IS_AD_old:** A boolean flag indicating if the STST adaptation was successfully performed (previous value).
*   **LV_RST_INH_STST_IS_AD_old:** A boolean signal indicating if STST inhibition must be reset (previous value).
*   **CTR_ST_STST_IS_AD_old:** The previous value of the STST adaptation counter.
*   **CTR_THD_ST_STST_IS_AD_old:** Counter threshold for STST adaptation frequency.

## Outputs

*   **LV_STST_STOP_INH_TQLO_AD:**  STST Stop Inhibition Request signal (adapted).
*   **LV_FIRST_STST_IS_AD:** A boolean flag indicating if this is the first STST adaptation attempt (current value).
*   **LV_END_STST_IS_AD:**  A boolean flag indicating if STST adaptation was successfully performed (current value).
*   **CTR_ST_STST_MNG_REQ:** Signal to increment or decrement the adaptation cycle counter.
*   **CTR_ST_STST_IS_AD:**  The current value of the STST adaptation counter.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Enable Check and Initial Conditions:** The process begins with an "Enable" input and checks for suitable conditions via the "LV_TEMP_ENG_AD_CDN_IS" input and previous STST state (using `LV_FIRST_STST_IS_AD_old`). If the 'Enable' is active, engine temp adaptation conditions are met and it's not the first adaptation attempt or an adaptation was already performed the previous cycle.

2.  **Torque Deviation Comparison:** It compares the current torque deviation (`TQ_DIF_I_IS`) with a threshold (`C_TQ_DIF_I_IS_AD_REQ`).

3.  **Adaptation Success/Failure:**
    *   If the torque deviation is *lower* than the threshold, it indicates adaptation is not required, and the  `LV_END_STST_IS_AD` flag is set to TRUE (adaptation successfully performed).
    *   If the torque deviation is *higher* than the threshold, adaptation is needed, and `LV_END_STST_IS_AD` remains FALSE (adaptation not yet successful).

4.  **Counter Update Logic:**  A counter (`CTR_ST_STST_IS_AD`) is updated based on the adaptation state and other flags.
    *   `CTR_ST_STST_MNG_REQ` Signal controls the counter update and is outputted according to whether the torque deviation is higher than the threshold or not. It indicates if the counter should be incremented or decremented.
    *   A 'Saturation' block limits the counter's range.
    *   The counter value is set to zero if it is at Check = 0.

5.  **Inhibition Request Generation:** An STST inhibition request (`LV_STST_STOP_INH_TQLO_AD`) is generated when a certain number of engine starts occur without successful torque adaptation.  This is determined by comparing the counter value (`CTR_ST_STST_IS_AD`) with a threshold (`CTR_THD_ST_STST_IS_AD_old`). If the counter exceeds the threshold, the inhibition request is activated.

6.  **Reset and State Preservation:**
    *   If `LV_RST_INH_STST_IS_AD_old` is asserted, or the engine adaptation conditions are not met, the `CTR_ST_STST_IS_AD` is reset to zero.
    *   The current values of important flags (`LV_FIRST_STST_IS_AD`, `LV_END_STST_IS_AD`, `CTR_ST_STST_IS_AD`) are propagated to the next iteration using unit delay blocks (represented by 'z^-1'), which preserve the system's state.

7.  **Output Flags:** The current `LV_END_STST_IS_AD` and `LV_FIRST_STST_IS_AD` flags are also passed to the output ports.

*   The current values of important flags (`LV_FIRST_STST_IS_AD`, `LV_END_STST_IS_AD`, `CTR_ST_STST_IS_AD`) are propagated to the next iteration using unit delay blocks (represented by 'z^-1'), which preserve the system's state.

7.  **Output Flags:** The current `LV_END_STST_IS_AD` and `LV_FIRST_STST_IS_AD` flags are also passed to the output ports. The overall signal `LV_STST_STOP_INH_TQLO_AD` becomes the final request for STST inhibition, based on adaptation conditions and the state of the internal counter.

## Function

This Simulink diagram calculates and averages torque losses for an engine cylinder bank.  It determines the actual valve lift position and uses it, along with other inputs, to look up and calculate the torque losses.

## Inputs

*   **NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_IN**: Intake valve timing index.
*   **NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_EX**: Exhaust valve timing index.
*   **MAF_STK_CBK_i_k**: Mass Air Flow Stack value (Bank i, Cylinder k)
*   **CAM_IN_i**: Intake Cam Position (Bank i)
*   **CAM_EX_k**: Exhaust Cam Position (Cylinder k)
*   **NR_ACK_CBK_VVL_i**: Number of cylinders with active valve lift, bank i.
*   **NR_ACK_CBK_VVL_i_old**: Previous value of the Number of cylinders with active valve lift, bank i.
*   **IDX_TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i_in**: Index for Torque Loss Engine, Bank, Cylinder Selection.

## Outputs

*   **TQFR_CBK_SEL_i_k**: Torque Friction, Cylinder Bank Selection (Bank i, Cylinder k)
*   **TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i_k**: Torque Loss, Engine, Cylinder Bank Selection (Bank i, Cylinder k)
*   **TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL**: Torque Loss, Engine, Cylinder Bank Selection
*   **TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i**:  Torque Loss, Engine, Cylinder Bank Selection (Bank i)
*   **IDX_TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i_out**: Index for Torque Loss Engine, Bank, Cylinder Selection Out.

## Logic Flow

The diagram can be broken down into two sections:  Cam Angle lookup and Torque Loss Determination.

**Cam Angle Lookup (Top Section):**

1.  **Two 2D Lookups:** Two 2D lookup tables named "IP_TQFR_VVL_CAM" and "IP_TQFR_VVL_CAM_RAM" generate intermediate values based on the following inputs:
    *   Lookup 1 Inputs: `NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_IN`, `NC_NR_IDX_IVVT_EX`, `MAF_STK_CBK_i_k`
    *   Lookup 2 Inputs: `CAM_IN_i`, `CAM_EX_k`
2.  **Intermediate value:** `IP_TQFR_VVL_CAM` and `TQFR_CBK_SEL_i_k` represent the outputs of the two lookups.
3.  **Summation:** A constant `TOFR_COR` is added to `TQFR_CBK_SEL_i_k`, resulting in  `TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i_k`.

**Torque Loss Determination (Bottom Section):**

1.  **Flip-Flop (FF):** The "FF" block implements a flip-flop. The `NR_ACK_CBK_VVL_i` (current valve lift position) is compared with `NR_ACK_CBK_VVL_i_old` (previous valve lift position) using "greater than" and "less than" blocks, the outputs from comparators feed the `SET` and `RST` inputs of the Flip-Flop block. This logic determines the trigger signal for the flip-flop.
2.  **Flip-Flop Output:** The output `Q` of the flip-flop controls the next section.
3.  **2-D Lookup Table:** A direct lookup table named "DirectLookup" uses the output of the Flip-Flop and `TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL` as index values. The output of this Direct Lookup block is `TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i`
4.  **Summation:** The input  `TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL` is generated after multiplying the Flip-Flop output by a Constant value. A delay block holds the value of TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i to generate previous value of valve lift `IDX_TQ_LOSS_ENG_CBK_SEL_i_out`

**Overall:**

The system determines torque losses based on engine operating conditions and valve lift position. The flip-flop and comparators create a signal that triggers on changes in valve lift activation. The Lookup Table and other elements then determine the torque losses.

## Function
The flowchart outlines the steps required to calibrate the idle speed adaptation algorithm in an automotive engine control system. This process ensures that the engine idles smoothly and efficiently under various operating conditions.

## Inputs
The inputs to the process are not explicitly shown in the diagram but implicitly include:
*   Engine speed
*   Engine load
*   Throttle position
*   Ignition timing
*   Idle Speed Controller (ISC) parameters

## Outputs
The primary output is a calibrated Idle Speed Adaptation algorithm and controller that maintains a stable idle speed under different driving and environmental conditions.

## Logic Flow
The process follows these steps:

1.  **Switch off the idle speed controller:** This involves setting all maps to zero or using default data for the adaptation algorithm. The engine is checked to ensure it can run self-stabilized without the active idle speed controller and without any additional load. The engine and system pre-requisites are also verified.
2.  **Start the tuning of the ISC with Torque reserve functionality:** This involves tuning the Idle Speed Controller (ISC) when the engine is under low speed and compensating through torque reserve functionality.
3.  **Tuning of the I-part of the controller:** The Integral part of the controller, likely a PID controller, is tuned to eliminate steady-state errors in idle speed.
4.  **Tuning of the PD-part of the controller:** The Proportional-Derivative parts of the PID controller are tuned to improve transient response and reduce oscillations in idle speed.
5.  **Calibration of the Idle Speed adaptation algorithm:** The entire idle speed adaptation algorithm is then calibrated.
6.  **Overall Test:** The calibrated system undergoes an overall test to verify its performance under various conditions.
7.  **Calibration of ISC with Drivetrain engaged:** The final step involves calibrating the ISC with the drivetrain engaged, simulating real-world driving conditions.
